Posts.Content: Hi! My name is Leigh Ann. I have recently taken a position in a new breast surgeon's office, as office coordinator in Greenville, South Carolina. Up until now, Greenville (a very large city) didn't have a specialty breast surgeon, so this is very exciting for our community. I really enjoy working in this office; however, there are days when things are unbearable...seeing patients diagnosed with breast cancer. I have seen ladies in their 20's and up being diagnosed, and it's terrible that we haven't found a cure. Wouldn't it be wonderful if 2008 were the year for the cure? It breaks my heart, especially seeing the women with young children being diagnosed with this dreadful disease.  My question is...does anyone know of any group of ladies who like to sew, knit or crochet for the cause. I have seen in other offices, where they have the little pillows for the pt's to take home after having axillary dissection (this is where they take many lymph nodes from under the arm). This is a very painful procedure, and normally this patient is unable to rest their arm against their body for quiet some time. The pillows are very useful, and serve as a great purpose...and I'm sure most patients end up keeping those for the rest of their lives as a reminder of a turning point in their lives....when they began the fight. There are many things that crafty ladies could donate...ex. chemo caps, pillows, ribbon pins....etc. I'm sure there are many I'm not aware of.  If any of you have any ideas, resources, advice...etc, please email me at --Message edited by CancerCompass staff. For personal protection, email address removed. Consider private reply. Please review CancerCompass Member Guidelines at http://www.cancercompass.com/common/guidelines.html-- , and I will gladly return your emails. I appreciate any and all help. Thank you in advance, Leigh Ann M

Posts.Content: On 2/9/2008 Leemg wrote: I read your message and just had to write.  No, I personally am not crafty at all nor do I know someone or a group who could help.  But, I wanted to thank you as a BC 4+ year survivor for your compassion in promoting this project for the woman whom you see on a day to day basis.  I agree, the sadest of all are those woman in their 20's and 30's who either have young children or have not even reached that area of their life.  I'm so happy your area now has a breast specialist for these woman so many can be saved if their cancers are found and treated early.  God bless people like yourself who are engaging in the cause if not to cure, to help woman get through this ordeal a little easier, and to let them know someone cares and is cheering them on.  Thank you so much for the reply. For it is people like you who make me want to fight harder for the cure. I am so happy you are a survivor, and I love you positive attitude. I have no doubt that your positive attitude played a great role in your winning against the BC.

Posts.Content: On 2/15/2008 Ruth601 wrote: I would check with your local hospital and see if there is a ladies auxilliary group who does things like this.  Or perhaps local chuch women's groups do this type of work.  I have a friend who is in a ladies group at her church who do this type of work, but I live in New Jersey so I don't think they would ship stuff to you.  But I'm sure there are probably churches in Greenville that have ladies groups of this type. Thank you! I will definitely look into that.
